result.execSummary:
The defendant Latricia B King was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Attempt Obtain Controlled Substance by Fraud [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.43(1)(a).
  • Misappropriate ID Info - Obtain Money [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.201(2)(a).
  • Theft-Movable Property <=$2500, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Milwaukee County Clerk of Circuit Court

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: With any other sentence with credit for 0 days.

miscConds.notes:
*Court ordered the defendant pay all of the following by the end of supervision.  Failure to pay will result in a civil judgment: All court costs, fees, and surcharges (including DNA); All applicable fees of supervision- paid under budget plan.
*If revoked, the Court ordered that all court costs, fines, surcharges be paid through collection by the Department of Corrections from 25% of funds under Sec. 973.05(4)(b) and as a condition of extended supervision. DOC shall collect those sums.  Any amount remaining due and owing is subject to civil judgment.
*Court orders restitution set at zero.
*Provide a DNA sample.

*No firearms or ammunition.
*Court advised defendant that as a convicted felon she may never possess a firearm. Court advised defendant that she may not vote until her civil rights have been restored.

*Submit to probation agent a 100 word essay about 5 people who died in the past year regarding what their lives were like prior to opiate overdose.
*Follow all rules of supervision and follow through with any other treatment deemed necessary by the department.

*AODA assessment if deemed appropriate by the department and cooperate with any programs deemed necessary
*Absolute/maintain sobriety, no alcohol, no drugs
*Random urine screens if deemed appropriate by the department

timeConds.notes: *1st 5 months straight time, last 4 months with release privileges- STAYED until 4-15-16, 5pm.

records.addlTxt:
Defendant Latricia B King in court with attorney Joseph R Kennedy.  Patricia Irene Daugherty appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Deputy Court Clerk: dds.

Sentencing proceeded.  Statements made by State, defense and defendant. 
 
COUNT 1:  The Court sentenced the defendant to a MAXIMUM TERM OF IMPRISONMENT of 2 YEARS, CONCURRENT to any other sentence with credit for 0 days. The INITIAL TERM OF CONFINEMENT in the Wisconsin State Prison System is 1 YEAR.  The MAXIMUM TERM OF EXTENDED SUPERVISION IS 1 YEAR.


COUNT 3:  The Court sentenced the defendant to a MAXIMUM TERM OF IMPRISONMENT of  6 YEARS, CONCURRENT to Count 1 with credit for 0 days. The INITIAL TERM OF CONFINEMENT in the Wisconsin State Prison System is 3 YEARS.  The MAXIMUM TERM OF EXTENDED SUPERVISION IS 3 YEARS.

The defendant IS NOT eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program or the Substance Abuse Program.  

The Court STAYED these sentences and placed the defendant on probation for a period of 3 YEARS.

COUNT 5:  The Court ordered the defendant to serve 6 MONTHS in the House of Correction, CONCURRENT to Counts 1 and 3 with 0 days credit.  

The Court STAYED this sentence and placed the defendant on probation for a period of 1 YEAR.

Conditions of Probation/ Extended Supervision if revoked:
-As to Count 1:  Serve 9 months condition time- 1st 5 months straight time, last 4 months with release privileges- STAYED until 4-15-16, 5pm.
-Submit to probation agent a 100 word essay about 5 people who died in the past year regarding what their lives were like prior to opiate overdose
-AODA assessment if deemed appropriate by the department and cooperate with any programs deemed necessary
-Absolute/maintain sobriety, no alcohol, no drugs
-No possession/consumption/selling/distribution of illegal drugs/alcohol
-Random urine screens if deemed appropriate by the department
-Obtain/maintain fulltime employment/education/vocation
-Complete 100 hours of community service
-No firearms or ammunition
-Provide a DNA sample
-Follow all rules of supervision and follow through with any other treatment deemed necessary by the department.

Court ordered the defendant pay all of the following by the end of supervision.  Failure to pay will result in a civil judgment:
All court costs, fees, and surcharges (including DNA); 
All applicable fees of supervision- paid under budget plan.

If revoked, the Court ordered that all court costs, fines, surcharges be paid through collection by the Department of Corrections from 25% of funds under Sec. 973.05(4)(b) and as a condition of extended supervision. DOC shall collect those sums.  Any amount remaining due and owing is subject to civil judgment.  Court orders restitution set at zero.

Court advised defendant that as a convicted felon she may never possess a firearm. 
Court advised defendant of her right to seek postconviction relief.
Court advised defendant that she may not vote until her civil rights have been restored.  

Filed:  
Written Explanation of Determinate Sentence-copy to defendant
Notice of Right to Seek Postconviction Relief
Ineligible Voting Notice & Acknowledgement
Sentencing Referral Form
Character letters submitted on behalf of the defendant, filed.

Defendant Latricia B King in court with attorney Joseph R Kennedy.  Patricia Irene Daugherty appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Case in court for final pre-trial. Court vacates the jury trial scheduled for 3/14/2016.

As to Counts 1, 3 & 5:
Defendant changes plea to GUILTY. Defendant examined as to her plea, advised of her Constitutional rights and the maximum penalty. Court found that defendant freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived her rights. Plea questionnaire received and filed. Parties stipulate to the complaint as a factual basis to sustain defendant's plea. Court found defendant guilty as charged in the information and ordered a Judgment of Conviction be entered on the record. Defendant is advised she is a convicted felon and may not possess any firearms. Defendant is advised she is unable to vote in any election until civil rights are restored. Defendant further advised that if she is not a US citizen deportation is possible.  Sentencing hearing scheduled for April 5, 2016 at 01:30 pm.

Status conference scheduled for November 18, 2015 at 08:30 am.
